summary: Frederick C. Randall is mentioned in several documents related to CIA personnel and investigations. He appears in a list of CIA personnel assigned to the Tokyo Station, indicating his involvement with the CIA in Tokyo. He is also mentioned in a contact report regarding James Wilcott's allegations about Lee Harvey Oswald being a CIA agent while stationed in Tokyo. Additionally, his name appears in a collection of documents related to FOIA requests and classification reviews. Finally, he is mentioned in a memorandum regarding Edwin Anderson Walker.
significance: Frederick C. Randall's significance in the JFK context stems from his association with the CIA and his presence in documents related to investigations into Lee Harvey Oswald's alleged connections to the CIA while stationed in Tokyo. His role as a CIA personnel assigned to the Tokyo Station places him within the network of individuals scrutinized in the aftermath of the assassination, particularly concerning allegations of Oswald's involvement with the agency.
